chapter.title: Configuring Your System
chapter.para: This chapter contains information on configuring your system.

sect1.title: Desktop Tricks
sect1.para: This section details some tips for using and customising Ubuntu's desktop environment (called GNOME), and the file manager (called Nautilus).

sect2.title: Adding and rearranging menu items
sect2.para: If you installed a program but it is missing from the menu, or if you want to make other changes to the menu, you can alter it using the menu editor. Open it by choosing &menu-editor;, or by right-clicking on any top-level menu and choosing Edit Menus.

To add a menu entry, choose the appropriate category on the left, then click New Entry. In the Entry Editor window, the Name field is the text that will appear in the menu, and the Browse button lets you choose the file you want to add an entry for.
To move an item, select it, then click the arrow buttons on the right.
To remove an entry, uncheck its checkbox. You can restore it later by checking the box again.

sect2.title: Start a Program Manually
sect2.para: Sometimes it can be useful to start a program manually, for example when the program does not have an entry in the menu. This is easy to do with the Run Applications dialogue.
For an application you intend to use regularly that does not have a menu entry, it is also very easy to add a menu entry to Ubuntu. (see )

step.para: Open the Run Applications window by typing Alt F2 .
Enter the name of the program you wish to run, and press Enter.

sect2.title: Run programs automatically when Ubuntu starts

step.para: Choose &sessions;.
Click on Startup Programs.
Use the Add, Edit, and Delete buttons to manage programs to run at startup. Some programs will automatically add themselves to this list when you configure them.

sect2.title: Log in automatically when the computer starts
sect2.para: To log in automatically when the computer starts:

step.para: Choose &login-screen-setup;.
Select Security, and turn on Enable Automatic Login.
Choose the account you want to log in as.

sect2.para: This is not recommended for most computers, as it is not secure and may give other people access to your information.

sect2.title: Change Display Mode in Nautilus
sect2.para: Ubuntu's file manager Nautilus provides two modes in which you can interact with your filesystem: Spatial mode and Browser mode.

listitem.para: In Browser mode, the file manager window represents a browser, which can display any location. Opening a folder updates the current file manager window to show the contents of the new folder.

In Spatial mode, the file manager window represents a particular folder. Opening a folder opens the new window for that folder. Each time you open a particular folder, you will find its window displayed in the same place on the screen and the same size as the last time you viewed it (this the reason for the name).

sect2.para: Browser mode is the default setting on Ubuntu, but you may wish to change this:

step.para:
In Nautilus, choose
Edit Preferences .
Click on the Behavior tab.
Unselect the Always open in browser windows check box.
Close and reopen Nautilus.

sect2.title: Show hidden files and folders in Nautilus
sect2.para:
In Nautilus, use the Ctrl H shortcut keys to toggle hidden files and folders on and off, or select
View Show Hidden Files .
To permanently show all hidden files and folders:

step.para: Edit Preferences .
Click on the Views tab.
Select the Show hidden and backup files check box.

sect2.title: Open the Location Bar in Nautilus
sect2.para:
The Location Bar is the bar in your file manager in which you can type an address. Toggle the bar on and off with:
Go Location...
You can also use the Ctrl L shortcut keys.

sect2.title: View remote SSH, FTP, and SFTP servers using Nautilus

step.para: Make sure the Nautilus Location Bar is open (see ).
For an SSH server, enter in the location bar: ssh://username@ssh.server.com
For an FTP server, enter: ftp://username@ftp.server.com
For an SFTP server, enter: sftp://username@sftp.server.com

Replace username with your username and replace everything after the @ symbol with the server's address. You will be prompted for a password if needed. If there is no username (anonymous), omit the username and the @ symbol.
You can enter your password as part of the address by including it immediately after the username, with a : character between them. For example: ftp://username:password@ftp.server.com

To access remote servers easily through Nautilus, add a permanent bookmark to the server by selecting
Places Connect to Server... and entering the details for the remote server.

sect2.title: Change the default Open with program for a file type

step.para:
In Nautilus, right click on the file and choose
Properties
from the menu that appears. The Properties dialog opens.
Click on the Open With tab. A list of applications appears.
Select the default application you want for the file type. If the application is not on the list, use the Add button to add the application to the list.

sect2.title: Open files with administrative privileges from the file manager
sect2.para: To open files with administrative privileges from the file manager, you need to add a script to Nautilus.

warning.para: Opening files with administrative privileges is a security risk. Always ensure that you are familiar with the file that you are opening.

step.para:
Open a new file to edit in the relevant directory:
gedit $HOME/.gnome2/nautilus-scripts/Open\ as\ Administrator
Enter these lines in the new file:
step.programlisting: for uri in $NAUTILUS_SCRIPT_SELECTED_URIS; do gksudo "gnome-open $uri" & done

step.para: Save the edited file (an example)
Make the edited file executable: chmod +x $HOME/.gnome2/nautilus-scripts/Open\ as\ Administrator

sect2.para: You can now open a file as an administrator by right-clicking on it and choosing Scripts Open as Administrator .

sect2.para: gDesklets is a system for bringing mini programs (desklets), such as weather forecasts, news tickers, system information displays, or music player controls, onto your desktop, in a symbiotic relationship of eye candy and usefulness.

step.para: Install the gdesklets and gdesklets-data packages from the Universe repository (see ).

Choose:
Applications Accessories gDesklets
For more information, visit the gDesklets website

step.para: Open the Configuration Editor, by running the program gconf-editor (see ).

Choose
apps nautilus desktop .
Turn on computer_icon_visible, home_icon_visible, and trash_icon_visible. The changes take effect immediately.

sect2.title: Changing your preferred email client to Mozilla Thunderbird

step.para: Choose &preferred-applications;
Click on the Mail Reader tab, and select the Custom option.

In the Command text box, type
mozilla-thunderbird %s, then close the dialog.

sect2.title: Restart GNOME without rebooting the computer

step.para: Save and close all open applications.

Use the Ctrl Alt Backspace
shortcut keys to restart GNOME.

If Ctrl Alt Backspace
is disabled, type sudo /etc/init.d/gdm restart
(See to disable Ctrl Alt Backspace .)

sect2.title: Preventing the Ctrl-Alt-Backspace shortcut keys from restarting X

step.para: Make a backup copy of your existing /etc/X11/xorg.conf file: sudo cp /etc/X11/xorg.conf /etc/X11/xorg.conf_backup
Open /etc/X11/xorg.conf for editing: sudo gedit /etc/X11/xorg.conf
Add the following lines to the end of the file: Section "ServerFlags" Option "DontZap" "yes" EndSection
Save the edited file (an example).
The change will take effect the next time you log in to GNOME. If you want the change to take effect immediately, restart GNOME manually. (See .)

sect2.title: Graphical Partition Editor
sect2.para: Gparted is a graphical tool to edit disk partitions.

step.para: Install the gparted package (see ).
You can run the application with &gparted;.

sect2.title: Make partitions available from Ubuntu
sect2.para: Windows and other partitions should be automatically available from any Ubuntu system. If they are not, you can make them available using the Disks Manager.

step.para: Open &disks;.
Select the correct hard disk, and click Partitions.
Select the relevant partition, and click Enable.
To unmount the partition, click Disable.

sect2.title: Make partitions automatically available
sect2.para: Again, Windows and other partitions should be automatically available from Ubuntu. If they are not, the following procedure will make them automatically available:

step.para: Read
First make a directory where the partition can be made available ("mounted"):
Next, back up your disk configuration file and open the file in a text editor with administrative privileges:
Append the following line at the end of file: /dev/hda1 /media/windows ntfs umask=0222 0 0

note.para: Replace /dev/hda1 with the correct device name for your partition.
If your Windows partition uses the FAT32 filesystem, replace ntfs with vfat in the above command.
If you have a FAT32 filesystem, it is also safe to allow read-write access. To do this, change the value of umask to 0000.

step.para: Save the edited file (an example).
The changes will take effect when the computer is restarted.

sect2.para: This requires administrative privileges (see ).

step.para:
Run Services Settings:

Enter your password.
Tick/untick the services you want running, then click OK when done.

sect2.title: Digital Cameras
sect2.para: Ubuntu detects most USB digital cameras automatically. Plug in and switch on the camera, and Ubuntu will then ask you if you would like to import the photos it contains. Click on Import, and Ubuntu will show you a preview of the photos. Choose a location to save your photos to, then click on Import, and Ubuntu will save your photos to your hard drive.
If Ubuntu does not ask you if it can import the photos:

step.para: Open >humb;.

Choose
File Import Photos .

sect2.para: See for more on gThumb.

sect3.para: Most video hardware should work automatically with Ubuntu. With some types of video hardware, 3D acceleration (which is needed by some games) is not supported automatically, but you may be able to fix this yourself.
To find out whether 3D acceleration is working, enter in a terminal:
If 3D acceleration is working, the result will be: direct rendering: Yes If not, follow these instructions to activate 3D acceleration.

sect3.title: 3D Nvidia Video Card Driver
sect3.para: No Nvidia Video cards have 3D acceleration enabled automatically with Ubuntu, because the manufacturer does not release open source drivers. However, it is possible to activate 3D acceleration. The process depends on which type of video card you have.

listitem.para: If you have an older TNT, TNT2, TNT Ultra, GeForce1 or GeForce2 card, install the nvidia-glx-legacy and nvidia-settings packages from the Restricted repository (see ).
If you have a newer card, install the nvidia-glx package from the Restricted repository (see ).

You can adjust the settings of the new drivers by running nvidia-settings (see ). If you wish, add a menu entry for this program (see ).

sect2.title: Keyboard Layouts
sect2.para: The keyboard layout determines which character appears when you press each key on the keyboard. If the wrong letter or symbol appears when you press a particular key, you probably need to change the keyboard layout. If you often type in more than one language, you may need to switch between multiple keyboard layouts.

sect3.title: Add a Layout
sect3.para: To add a keyboard layout to your system:

step.para: Open SystemPreferencesKeyboard.
Choose Layouts, and click Add. It is simpler to have two layouts; the maximum is currently four.

sect3.title: Switch Keyboard Layouts
sect3.para: You can set a keyboard combination to switch between keyboard layouts:

step.para: Open SystemPreferencesKeyboard.
Click Layouts, then use the Add and Remove buttons to choose the keyboard layouts you want to be able to switch between.

Click Layout Options, then Group Shift/Lock behaviour, and choose the key combination for switching layouts that’s most convenient for you. The default combination is pressing both Alt keys at the same time; a common alternative is AltShift.

sect3.title: Keyboard Indicator
sect3.para: The Keyboard Indicator displays which keyboard layout you are using, and lets you switch to other layouts using the mouse.
To display the Keyboard Indicator:

step.para: Right-click on an empty space on the panel where you want the indicator, and choose Add to Panel.
From the Utilities section, choose Keyboard Indicator.

sect3.para: To change the keyboard layout, click the Keyboard Indicator with the primary mouse button. For other options, click it with the secondary mouse button.

sect2.title: Wireless Cards
sect2.para: Many wireless cards are automatically detected by Ubuntu during installation. A complete listing of wireless cards which work with Ubuntu can be found on Ubuntu Wiki. Please add your wireless card to the list if it works with Ubuntu.

Some cards may not work automatically with Ubuntu. If this is the case, please look at the Wireless Troubleshooting Guide on the Ubuntu Wiki which is an excellent resource for troubleshooting wireless cards.
All information regarding wireless networking on Ubuntu is collected at Wireless Networking Central on the Ubuntu Wiki.

sect3.title: Winmodems
sect3.para: Most winmodems are not supported by Ubuntu, but drivers can be found that will enable the use of such modems. First you need to identify what chipset your winmodem is using:

para.screen: wget -c &scanmodem-url; gunzip -c &scanmodem-gz; > scanModem chmod +x scanModem sudo ./scanModem gedit Modem/ModemData.txt

sect3.para: Read this file, it should list what modem chipset you have. Once you are aware of the chipset you have, see &linmodem; and follow the directions for your modem. More infomation can be found at SettingUpModems on the Ubuntu Wiki.

sect3.title: ADSL Modems
sect3.para: All PPPOE and router-style ADSL modems that use an Ethernet connection are supported by Ubuntu, and some USB ADSL modems are supported too. For a router-style ADSL modem, connect it and configure it as instructed by your ISP before configuring networking in Ubuntu. For information on PPPOE modems see this guide on the Ubuntu wiki.

sect2.title: Printers
sect2.para:
Some printers will be automatically detected by Ubuntu; for those that are not, choose &printing;, then choose
Printer Add Printer .
Some printers need further setup. Search the databases at LinuxPrinting.org or check the Ubuntu Wiki's Printer page for possible information on your printer.

Select the Harddrive, then the Partitions tab

sect2.title: Change the Computer Name

step.para: Open &networking;.
Click General, and enter the name of the computer in the Hostname field.

sect2.para: Restart the computer for the change to take effect.

sect3.title: Firestarter Firewall
sect3.para: A firewall protects a computer system from unauthorized access. It is not normally necessary to install a firewall on an Ubuntu system, because access to the system is closed by default. However, if you run any services that let other computers access yours (for example, the Apache web server), it is advisable to install a firewall. Firestarter is a program that lets you control a firewall through a graphical interface.

step.para: Install the Firestarter package from the Universe repository (see ).
After it is installed, run &firestarter-firewall-tool; to configure your firewall. The firewall will now start in the background when your computer starts.

sect3.title: Graphical Network Monitor
sect3.para: Etherape displays network activity among different hosts using circles of varying size.

step.para: Install the etherape package from the Universe repository (see ).

Choose:
Applications Internet Etherape

sect3.title: Network Traffic Analyzer
sect3.para: Ethereal is a network traffic analyzer/sniffer that captures packets off the network in real time and displays their contents.

step.para: Install the ethereal package from the Universe repository (see ).

Choose:
Applications Internet Ethereal
